newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta weakens against mark as funds flow north.
newsitem.headline: Peseta weakens against mark as funds flow north.

text.p: The recent weakening of the peseta against the mark reflects in part a reversal in the flow of funds, which are now moving towards northern European currencies in search of greater returns, analysts said on Thursday.
The peseta has weakened against the mark after steaming through the key 84.00 per mark barrier earlier in January to around 83.35, the highest level since May last year.
By midday the peseta was trading at 83.78/80 per mark, after touching 83.94 earlier in the session and compared with 84.74/77 on Wednesday.

"The sudden pull-back of the peseta is linked to the weakening of the dollar/mark after its previous strong rise and a certain amount of transfer of funds toward northern European currencies in search of greater returns," said Antonio Villarroya, an analyst at Merrill Lynch in Madrid.
But he added that the swing had not been too severe.
On January 10, the peseta broke through the key 84.00 per mark barrier after the Bank of Spain released its grip and refrained from intervening.
Traders said the central bank had been selling pesetas for some months and was keen to hold the currency in the 84.00 to 85.00 per mark band in the run-up to a single European currency.
Considerable flows into Spain's bond and equity markets have exerted upward pressure on the peseta.
But analysts were predicting a continued weakening of the currency. "We continue to maintain our forecast that the peseta will return to 84.00 per mark," said Villarroya.
In his opinion, the peseta will trade in the coming months between 85.07 --the peseta's central parity rate in the European Monetary System-- and 83.17, a 2.25 percent fluctuation band.
Some analysts said the peseta could be weighed down as falls in Spanish debt yields reduce the attractiveness of Spain for overseas investors.
On Wednesday, one-year Treasury bill yields fell to a new low of 5.033 percent, and in coming auctions traders believe yields could slip under five percent.
With the spread of 10-year bonos to Bunds having narrowed to 90 basis points, investors have been moving into the short end of the yield curve, seeking value.
"The problem with the Spanish market now is the short end. The slope is very steep," said an analyst at a bank in Madrid.
